html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *leh₂t- (“to grant, to possess”). Cognate with Ancient Greek λάτρις (látris) and Proto-Germanic *lēþą.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈla.troː/, [ˈlˠa.t̪ɾoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈla.tro/, [ˈlaː.t̪rɔ]
  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈlat.roː/, [ˈlˠat̪.roː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈlat.ro/, [ˈlat̪.rɔ]

Noun[edit]

latrō m (genitive latrōnis); third declension

  1. mercenary
  2. highwayman; brigand, bandit; robber
    Synonym: latrunculus
  3. chessman, pawn
    Synonym: latrunculus
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative latrō latrōnēs
Genitive latrōnis latrōnum
Dative latrōnī latrōnibus
Accusative latrōnem latrōnēs
Ablative latrōne latrōnibus
Vocative latrō latrōnēs
Related terms[edit]
  • latrīa
  • latrōcinālis
  • latrōcināliter
  • latrōcinātiō
  • latrōcinium
  • latrōcinor
  • latrunculārius
  • latrunculus
 
Descendants[edit]
descendants
  • Corsican: ladru, latru
  • Dalmatian: ladr
  • Emilian: lèder
  • Franco-Provençal: lârro
  • Friulian: lari, ladron
  • Istriot: laro
  • Ladin: lère
  • Lombard: làdar, lader, ladru (Leventina), lädar (Val Bregaglia)
  • Neapolitan: latro
  • Old French: lerre, larron, lasrun, larrun, ladron, ladrun
    • Middle French:
      • French: larron
    • Walloon: lâron
  • Italian: ladro, ladrone
  • Old Leonese:
    • Asturian: lladrón, ladrón
    • Mirandese: lhadron
  • Old Portuguese: ladron
    • Fala: lairon
    • Galician: ladrón
    • Portuguese: ladrão, ladraõ, ladro
      • → Angolar: ladron
      • Chinese Pidgin English: la-li-loong
      • Guinea-Bissau Creole: ladron
      • Indo-Portuguese: laderan
      • Kristang: ladrang
      • Principense: ladran
  • Old Occitan: laire, lairon
    • Old Catalan: lladre, lladró, lairó,
      • Catalan: lladre
  • Old Spanish: ladron
    • Ladino: ladrón
    • Spanish: ladrón
      • Chavacano: ladron
      • Palenquero: lairón
      • Papiamentu: ladron
      • → English: ladrone, ladron
  • Piedmontese: làder, ladrun
  • Romansch: lader, leder
  • Shona: ladrone
  • Sicilian: latru, latruni, larruni
  • Venetian: ladro, laro, ladron
  • → English: latron
  • → Welsh: lleidr

Etymology 2[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *leh₂- (expressive root). Cognate with lāmentum, Ancient Greek λῆρος (lêros), λάλος (lálos), λάσκω (láskō).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈlaː.troː/, [ˈlˠaː.t̪ɾoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈla.tro/, [ˈlaː.t̪rɔ]

Verb[edit]

lātrō (present infinitive lātrāre, perfect active lātrāvī, supine lātrātum); first conjugation

  1. I bark, bay
  2. I rant, bluster
  3. (of water) I roar.
  4. I demand vehemently
